item.title: Defense Evasion
item.description: 1. Introduction Link to heading EDR solutions a.k.a (Endpoint Detection and Response) are an evolution of the security software we know as antivirus. Modern EDRs use advanced techniques to detect threats, hooking APIs, isolating the host from the internet, analyzing behavior, and classifying detections based on Indicator of Compromise (IOC) rules classified by MITRE ATT&CK. In this article, I will demonstrate how to bypass EDRs using evasive techniques. 2. Technical Analysis Link to heading In a real attack, it is common to use “Loaders” and “Droppers” that load the main malware, going through stages.

item.title: Rootkits in Firmware
item.description: What is a Rootkit? Link to heading A rootkit is a type of malware designed to gain and maintain privileged access to a system while hiding its presence. The term comes from the combination of “root”, which refers to the user with maximum privileges on Linux systems, and “kit” which represents a set of tools used to control the compromised system The main purpose of a rootkit is to ensure persistence, allowing an attacker to continue accessing the system even after reboots or removal attempts.

item.title: Windows Architecture
item.description: Prerequisites: Requirements for the users that are planning to learn Malware Development are first of all basics of programming, since mostly deals with the C programming lanaguage, it is a requirement that you are familiar with fundamentals of C. So what is actually Windows Architecture? It is what happens under the hood of Windows processes and applications, the internal structure of the Windows operating system, envolves layers like hardware, kernel, executive services, and subsystem DLLs.
